oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Crispus Attucks Day commemoration with Doolittle Elemtary School students
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: H. A. Martin Photography
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: William Brandon, left, of 8574 S. Avalon Ave., education specialist in the Chicago Urban League's Community Services Department, meets group of Doolittle Elementary School students during Crispus Attucks Day celebrations held recently at 35th Street and South Parkway Ave. On the extreme right is Edward R. Smith, teacher at Doolittle. Following the annual event which is sponsored by the Chicago Insurance Association, Brandon and Smith briefly discussed the League programw [sic] in the education section of Community Services. Brandon noted that his job is to consult with, participate in and work with people in all levels throughout the city in order to achieve quality and equality in the Chicago Schools.

oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Career Day at Arthur Dixon Elementary School
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description:
It was "Career Day" for eighth graders at the Arthur Dixon Elementary School, 8306 S. St. Lawrence Avenue recently with Edwin C. Berry, third from Right, Executive Director of The Chicago Urban League delivering the keynote speech. Welcoming Berry to the program is Marcus Lyles, eighth grade president.
Others from left to right are Nina Greene of 8118 Eberhart Avenue, secretary; Mrs. Virginia Powe, eighth grade teacher; Charles E. Keenan, principal; Berry, Kenneth Taylor of 535 East 86th Street, vice president and Robin Miller, program chairman.
"A new world is opening up for the Black child who applies himself in school," Berry told the students. He further noted that "Black adults are committed to help make your future dreams a reality."

oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Reenlistment of Sgt. Irby Shears
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: "I solemnly swear that I will support the constitution of the U.S" This was part of the formal reenlistment proceedings recently completed by Sgt. Irby Shears. Having served four years, the 21 year old Chicagoan signed up for an additional three years with the U.S. Army recruiting division. His responsibilities will include touring Chicago high schools addressing the opportunities provided by the Army. Major John D. Spells, (left) area commander, U.S. Army recruiting, led the ceremonies held at the Chicago Urban League. Mr. Willie Gainer, CUL veterans affairs director, and Mr. James Taylor, CUL deputy executive director, programs, were on hand to witness the occasion. Left to right: John D. Spells, James Taylor, Willie Gainer, and Sgt. Irby Shears.

oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Delores Johnson welcomes new members to The Leaguers
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Bell, Ted
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Mrs. Delores Johnson, (left), president of The Leaguers, of 9311 S. Eberhart Ave., welcomes new members to the group, an official auxiliary of the Chicago Urban League as they kick-off their 13th Annual Benefit for the agency. The group organized in January, 1955 boasts of 25 members whose main goal is raising funds to assist the League with its annual budget. New Leaguers who are working untiringly for a successful benefit from left, are Mrs. Iris Jamerson, 9704 S. Emerald Ave., and Mrs. Patricia Matthews of 5207 S. Ingleside Ave. Mrs. Johnson stated that more than 2000 friends of The Leaguers are expected to attend the beneift [sic] ball on Sunday, March 2, at 10 p.m. in the Grand Ballroom of the Sheraton Chicago Hotel.
